review_title: Great experience at the Maternity Ward
job_title: Maternity Support Worker in London, England
pros: Meaningful and Rewarding Work: As a Maternity Support Worker at Guys and St Thomas NHS Foundation Trust, you have the opportunity to make a positive impact on the lives of mothers and their babies. Assisting with the delivery of high-quality care during pregnancy, labor, and postnatal stages can be incredibly fulfilling.
cons: High Workload and Demanding Shifts: Maternity support work can be physically and emotionally demanding. The workload can be heavy at times, especially during busy periods, which may lead to increased stress levels. Shift work, including nights and weekends, is also common, which can affect work-life balance and personal commitments.

review_title: Pretty good employer, as good as an NHS employer can be ....
pros: Great locations in the heart of London, amazing views from the top of the tower at Guy's. Staff are all friendly and general community atmosphere. Very flexible role (zero-hours contract).
cons: 12 hr shifts. Regarding specifically the vaccination team, management are greedy and expect the largely student-based workforce to work ridiculously hard for 12hrs per shift. On being given suggestions to make working conditions more amenable, staff were essentially ignored and do not feel heard. It's a shame because we work extremely hard leading to GSTT being at the forefront of the national vaccination effort, however sometimes we're pushed too hard.

review_title: Response to the review of ‘great hospital, bad IT senior managers’
job_title: Dont Want to Say in London, England
pros: The people, hardworking and nice.  Love working for the trust.  Clinical staff are second to none
cons:
There are some issues with senior management not following the values of the trust.  However, in response to the 14 Oct review, the information isn’t generally true.  The ex-TFL CEO was in fact a CIO and as he left several weeks ago, so the review given on the 14th Oct is null and void.  (There is now a new person in the role) 
No top dog is going to be liked by everyone and especially when that now CDIO starts rattling some cages and giving people who have been in trust (and department) for several years a kick up the backside to do what they’re actually being paid to do. 

The whole senior IT team shouldn’t be outsourced but they do need to start getting along and going forward in the same direction rather than separately according to their own career  goals.  

And ALL the former tfl staff? that would be about 5 people out of nearly 450-500 people and every senior director does that in a new role at some point.  I’ve seen it happen in several companies.  

As someone who has worked in the trust over several years and has seen the impact that directors have had on the teams, it wasn’t the ex-tfl boss that made those problems, it’s been this way for years.

pros: Some really great staff and team work

pros: The culture of the workplace is good
cons: It's a big London NHS Trust so there are lots of pressures

pros: Its quite a good place to work
cons: It can be too busy at times

review_title: Supportive and rewarding organisation to work for
pros: Supportive and opportunities for development
cons: Lots of pressure due to the pandemic

review_title: Difficult and frustrating place to work
pros: Nice location, good facilities for healthy eating and keeping active at work. I learnt a lot on this particular job which enabled me to move to a more senior job elsewhere.
cons: The Human Resources side of things is very lacking- wrong information about salary and pension sent out at job offer point, no response to queries, unable to speak to a person in HR ever. Line management is ridiculous- I was managed by a person in a different hospital who didn't know what I did. My job advert was not accurate. I received no training in the 10 months I worked here, no appraisal or performance review. IT systems out of date - worked on a computer with Office 2003, no internet access. No resources- had to buy my own pens, notebooks and post its etc.

review_title: A good clinical employer, but for those in professional services,  a stepping stone into a better job elsewhere
pros:
1) NHS pension, especially if you choose to have a long career in the NHS
2) Well known NHS trust in London with a good reputation 
3) If your clinical, than a good employer and I admire the front line staff. 
4) Charismatic friendly CEO who does her best 
5) My team / line manager was great, but I chose to leave for career advancement
cons:
1) I did not work in a clinical role, I worked in professional services where my skills, are transferable across to another employer out of the NHS, and I had seen various colleagues leave to non NHS organisations. 
2) Common knowledge the NHS is under-funded, and don't expect training as there is no budget.
3)  High turnover of staff, who leave to advance their careers 
4) Top heavy management

pros: The Trust is both big and friendly.  People, including the top management,  live by the Trust Values and really do put patients first.  There is always something new going on and there are lots of opportunities.  Being in the middle of London is also great.  It is a good feeling to work for an organisation that you know is leading the way in innovations in patient care.
cons: The cost of living is high in London, so a lot of people have to travel a long way to get to work.  The IT is not as up to date as it could be, so that can be frustrating.

review_title: Potentially a Great Place to Work
pros: Some great talent to work with or have working for you; some large budgets and exciting projects by virtue of the size of the Trust; seems to be a progressive Trust; great transport links to both sites
cons:
Whilst they have some good communication initiatives which should be applauded it's rarely focussed on engaging with staff as to how to make processes and practices more efficient and/or effective.

Some big awards can definitely be misleading and/or causing senior management to rest on their laurels eg Gold Award from Investors in People Award (unbelievable).

Too many examples - albeit a minority - of inauthentic leadership ie leaders very good at looking after their own interests and not their team's

review_title: Great Hospital but really bad senior IT Managers
pros: Clinical staff are just brilliant. Dedicated to a high degree, hard working, clear thinking.
cons: Their IT Management are frankly rubbish. They have a culture of bullying and incompetence. They bleat on about values and behaviours but they only use them when it suites them. Their big cheese, a useless ex TFL CEO is inane and incompetent. He's bypassed their own rules to bring his mates in from TFL and the rules be damned. They do not support the clinical staff and hide errors from them. They are as useful as a chocolate fireguard.  One of their errors resulted in very serious harm. I can't say here as they'll know who has written this.

job_title: IT Consultant/Project Manager in London, England
pros:
Good team.
The Trust's name is well respected.
The front-line staff who do a great job every day.
cons:
Hierarchical to the point where progress is hindered and tax payers money wasted.
Some management exhibit poor leadership where behaviours incongruent with the Trust's own values are shown regularly, including bullying.
Trust leadership unable or unwilling to actually do anything about poor performance (employment contracts don't have probationary periods) which extends all the way from those at the coal face all the way through to senior leadership. 
What's worse about this role is that working in a support function and being asked by interested parties, "what's it like working for the NHS?" my only answer now focuses on the significant waste of money currently taking place in the NHS, which is driven by poor leadership, lack of accountability, lack of government support for mass infrastructure redesign, and overall, a massively risk-averse appetite to change inherent within the quagmire of organisations that make up the NHS.

pros: This Trust stays ahead of the game, keeping up with and sometimes anticipating the twists and turns of government policy and initiatives. Great strategy! Financial management second to none.
cons: Higher management has become "distanced" from the workforce it represents. having said that there is a new conscious effort to correct that with managers being required to spend days at on the shop floor to re-connect with patients and staff. "Listening" exercises seem limited to hours when most staff are either too busy with their duties to attend or having a well-earned lunch break! More frequent "local" departmental events are required!

job_title: Service Delivery Manager in London, England
pros: Making a health service work smoothly is deeply satisfying and for many patients who use the NHS your activity as a service manager will improve their healthcare experience.
cons:
It's a demanding environment to work in, with potential outcomes that can be fatal. As a service manager you are the glue connecting the clinical with the admin backend and often a scapegoat when those two necessary work streams do not gel.
Promotion is hard, very few service managers progress.

job_title: Clinical Trial Coordinator in London, England
pros: Benefits of NHS pension, 27 days of annual leave, lots of like minded young people in the OHCT, get to build relationships with nurses, pharmacists, doctors and many more. Learn about cancer care, gain clinical experience
cons: Scope of progression, less jobs available at more senior levels, high staff turnover due to this, work can be stressful (never stops)

job_title: Commercial Finance Manager in London, England
pros: The Trust is as the heart of the NHS and provides the merit of socially useful involvement, while at the same time providing an environment for professional development and experience
cons: Employment terms and conditions are locked into national guidelines and while some effort is made to customise them to individual needs, this is at line management discretion and varies widely across the organisation

review_title: The NHS is a difficult place to work, but it is full of staff who want to make a difference for patients
job_title: Head of Engineering Operations in London, England
pros: Good working team, training, dedicated staff who ensure that the engineering services are available 24/7 so that patient care is not affected
cons: To much reliance on too few people leading to additional pressure on staff. Too many poor contractors handing over poor quality work to the hospital who are following poor quality designs. Too much bureaucracy in the NHS.

pros: Great hospital environment, great interest in patient care. There are some great managers that work here while others are quite lacking. Good opportunities to move around within the trust.
cons: Staffing and management issues, overworked nurses and doctors. At times the acuity of patients to nurse ratio can be unsafe. Low pay for the amount of work and stress required.

review_title: Went from permanent staff nurse to bank staff nurse
pros:
Easy to switch from permanent post to bank shifts
Easy access via e-roster to book shifts
Always shifts available
Good benefits for bank staff: pension, annual leave and sometimes sick pay
cons: After doing one bank shift I was blocked from working because human error within the admin team has meant that I am flagged as not fully trained when all of my training was completed in my first week in my previous post.

pros: Consultants and Nurses make the NHS, unfortunately not rewarded financially but with hollow words. They are being overworked and it is not safe.
cons: Inept, Incompetent, Incredulous and Insecure management. They pass down their work and blame and bully everyone else. They hire their friends and family to high paying positions who are much less qualified than other candidates. Overpaid and Underqualified management who are absolutely useless.

pros:
One of the largest NHS Trust in the UK
1.2 billion annual turnover
2 million patient contacts a year
Very good work environment
Work profile good
STP is excellent, you can get free training and MSc as well as salary
cons:
It is not about this Trust but NHS
Things are slow
Take longer to execute
Clinical Scientist training program not recognised outside the NHS, though it gives you a really good exposure.

review_title: Sadly had to leave an amazing team
pros: Interview was a panel of two people & questions were well suited; my team was mostly amazing; thorough trust induction; manager was supportive when I had to leave role
cons: Worry about taking time off sick; rostering can be difficult when other colleagues do set shifts; cost of living expensive compared to salary (even including inner London allowance)

job_title: IT Service Desk Analyst in London, England
pros:
Staff here are friendly
Workload is manageable
Perksatwork.com
NHS discouts
cons:
Pay is not competitive for an office based in Central London

Not a great place for progression, have to wait for the opportunities to come by every few months. 

Once you have the experience you're more likely to move elsewhere than stay in the trust.

job_title: Human Resources Administrator in London, England
pros:
Good location for both hospital
Well known and respected hospital
cons:
I had to leave as I was fed up of witnessing managers in HR's handlings of staff
HR did not resolve staff issues making them have to call back multiple times
My final pay was held which was not shocking as I had seen them do this before with other staff who chose to leave in the department as way to be spiteful this is against the law

job_title: Senior Clinical Research Nurse in London, England
pros: There is a feeling that the Trust cares about its staff- benefits are good. Cheap gym and pool membership. Encourages learning and undertaking courses. Good coffee shop and M&S on site of St Thomas'
cons: Canteen food is not the best and extremely expensive, even after discounted for staff. Very limited food options at Guy's

job_title: Clinical Research Practitioner in London, England
pros: Great place to learn  new things, but you have to fight for the opportunity to get access to train you up into a better role.
cons: Bad management of staff when flexible working. No support. Having a friend in management is very important if you want to improve your prospects.

review_title: The most disappointing trusts to work for.
pros:
Great location with fantastic views.
Easy to get to.
M&S and the addition of WHSmith.
cons:
Hospital does not care about staff. 
Staff are rude.
You get referred by your pay band only and treated as such so lowest pay bands get least respect.
Patient care is of the lowest quality. You won’t find one staff member implementing the 6 C’s. 
HR staff are abysmal.

pros: The opportunity to work with anonymity whilst having a supportive team and coaching/mentorship
cons: Insufficiently resourced, work life balance is dependent on your manager

pros:
Access to internal training
Friendly approachable team (I work in the community).
Good work life balance
cons:
Poor execution of projects - poor direction from management.
No clear local objectives or clear plan to execute these
Too much traveling
High staff turn over
Too many agency staff members

pros: Large Trust with significant funds. Worker-bees are dedicated and professional
cons: Engagement scores from staff survey are misleading. High staff turnover in parts of Essentia suggests all is not well.

job_title: Senior Medical Secretary in London, England
pros: Some of the best clinicians and research in the UK
cons: Inexperienced middle management who are also too young to have any life skills or experience managing people

pros: Good final salary pension.  No pressure to deliver.  Close to London Bridge station and an easy commute.
cons: No real commercial strategy.  Very naive and mercurial senior commercial people.  Overall Trus board not seemingly interested in the commercial directorate.  Lots of flitting between projects.  Good people leaving.

pros:
Always being treated with respect
Staff discounts
Training 
Events
Opportunity to grow
cons: Not very good work life balance if doing shift work

pros:
- Nice team
- Good reputation & achieving well as a Hospital
- Able to work with lots of skilled and talented people
- Good approach to flexible working
- Good location
- Lots of committed people that want to work hard
cons: I can't think of any

pros:
Hugely ambitious and well run health care organisation
Opportunity to gain experience and knowledge
Clinically excellent and reasonable non clinical management
cons:
Commercial and quite hard nosed
Can be stressful 
Subject to NHS pay terms

pros: Helpful friendly Staff,  easy access to floors and departments. Clear signposting and information boards.
cons: Too often certain lifts throughout the Hospital are either being repaired or refurbished, can cause delays during midday rush hour.

job_title: Senior Staff Nurse in London, England
pros: Good funding (by NHS standards), variety of specialties, training and promotions opportunities
cons: General NHS issues of being short staffed, SE1 post code but almost Central London therefore in congestion ULEZ area

review_title: Good place to start off career
pros: Job stability , in the city centre, good location, good staff
cons: lack of progression, when you are in the NHS you feel stuck

pros: Wonderful staff from all disciplines, with a genuine determination to do their best for patients
cons: Busy on call shift workload

pros: Good pension with the opportunity to work in different areas of the Trust
cons: Poor management with little career development and progression

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in London, England
pros:
- good benefits
- job stability
- research is an expanding and fun field
cons: - career prospects can be limited, particularly for those not a registered nurse

pros: Lots of training and career oportunities
cons: Not friendly at all, not even a smile, everyone is rushed and stressed

job_title: Heath Care Assistant in London, England
pros: I enjoy working at guys and st Thomas's because ,it is one best places to work.
cons: I don't have any down side

pros: Easy going, staff member will help out if needed
cons: micro managing, managers expect you to know everything. some of them moan every time and take it personally.

pros: Forward-thinking, good at recognising issues and making changes to improve the service.
cons: Living in London is expensive.

job_title: Clinical Pharmacy Specialist in London, England
pros: Good place to work, good people. Well structured department. Well led.
cons: Very large department. Can be difficult to get to know everyone.

job_title: Senior Fellow Interventional Radiology in London, England
pros:
Friendly, 
High quality of care and professional opportunities
High standard of training and education
cons:
Busy
Central location
Expensive Accomodation
Busy
Central location

pros: Great people, people care. Lots of room for development, very supportive. Great hospital to work at- the best
cons: There aren't really any cons

pros: good opportunities to work for nhs and it opens some doors
cons: not giving enough opportunities to minority group

pros: Great location. Easy access from anywhere.
cons:
Poor management. 
Inexperienced and unqualified employees at NHS band 7/8 roles.
Advertised job as permanent but after getting the job I was told there was no budget for permanent positions so I was on a temp basis... Where there was a large difference in salary than the advertised. Felt cheated .

pros: Staff are good, NHS structure as expected-not so good, would recommend
cons: Lack of resources if you do not work at main hospital site

pros: Amazing staff, colleagues and team to work for and induction process
cons: None as I loved working at this place

pros: Dignity, respect, good pay, fantastic team
cons: Very busy workload, a lot of things happening, can be confusing to start

pros: Large, strong community of friendly, experienced staff
cons: Similar with other large trusts, a LOT of bureaucracy and baffling organisational structures

cons: a lot of workneeds to be done

job_title: Clinical Trial Coordinator in London, England
pros: Clinical Team is supportive, great location, supportive, oppurtinity
cons: The team is Understaffed and too many trials for one person

pros: Great support network and opportunities to progress
cons: Staff areas are poor and lifts to the department are always over packed.

pros: Delivers excellent services despite usual challenges

cons: No standardisation or room for progression in the clinical trial department

cons: Hierarchical, bureaucratic and slow to adapt.
